title-group.article-title: Deep coalescent history of the hominin lineage

abstract.p: Coalescent-based methods are widely used to infer population size histories, but existing analyses have limited resolution for deep time scales (> 2 million years ago). Here we extend the scope of such inference by re-analysing an ancient peak seen in human and chimpanzee effective population size around 5-7 million years ago, showing that coalescent-based inference can be extended much further into the past than previously thought. This peak is consistently observed across human and chimpanzee populations, but not in gorillas or orangutans. We show that it is unlikely to be an artefact of model violations, and discuss its potential implications for understanding hominin evolutionary history, in particular the human-chimpanzee speciation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The study of human population size over time provides a valuable lens through which to explore key questions about our evolutionary past [1]. Population size history can be inferred from present day genome sequences by examining patterns of genetic variation within and between populations. Various methods have been developed for such inference, using information such as the site frequency spectrum, linkage disequilibrium, or the genomic distribution of heterozygosity. One popular method is the pairwise sequentially Markovian coalescent (PSMC) [2], as well as its successors [3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. These have enabled various insights the evolutionary history of humans, including the magnitude of exponential growth in the last 20 thousand years (kya), the timing and severity of the out of Africa bottleneck 50-60kya, and divergence times between various subpopulations as well as between humans, Neanderthals and Denisovans [8, 9].

Methods to infer human population size history have typically focused on studying evolution more recent than 1-2 million years ago (Mya). The mean coalescence time in humans is ∼1Mya, indicating that there should be information within a present day genome sequence to probe more ancient time scales. Insights into population size history beyond this period would be particularly interesting, as it may elucidate the emergence of the genera Homo (∼3Mya [10, 11]) and Australopithicus (∼4.5Mya [12]), or even the ancestral human-chimpanzee population (∼6Mya [13]). The inference of N(t) from some methods, including PSMC, do extend to this period, however it is typically not discussed in the existing literature. This may be because it has until now been unclear how robust inference is in those time frames, and in particular how badly the model is affected when its assumptions are violated.

Another set of methods uses cross-species analyses, in this case of present day sequences of humans, chimpanzees, and gorillas, to analyse the way in which these populations diverged. Methods such as CoalHMM and its successors employ coalescent hidden Markov model approaches, in which the hidden states correspond to the order of coalescent events, as well sometimes as ancestral coalescence times [14, 15, 16, 13, 17]. Typically the model parameters to be estimated are the divergence times and ancestral population sizes, which in turn are informative about the amount of incomplete lineage sorting (ILS) or gene flow. Some of these studies have suggested that the human-chimp speciation was “complex”, in that after initial population divergence there was a period of gene flow before final separation [18, 19, 13, 20], though others have suggested a clean split scenario [21, 22]. Many of these analyses make coarse assumptions about population size changes in the ancestral populations, and typically assume these were panmictic. Typically the size of the human-chimpanzee ancestral population is estimated to be very large, for example this is estimated as 167,400 in [17] and 177,368 in [23], both of which are more than 8 times the long-term effective population size of humans or chimpanzee. It is plausible that the size of the human-chimpanzee ancestral population really was extremely large, however it may be that this population was structured, which leads to inflated estimates of population size when assuming panmixia [24]. In this article we examine the changes in size of the ancestral human/chimp population in higher resolution and with fewer assumptions, finding a similar magnitude to that inferred in recent time.

So far existing methods have offered limited population genetic insight into human evolution between 1-2Mya and the divergence of the ancestral human/chimpanzee population around 6Mya [14, 13, 25]. Here, we examine the potential to broaden the scope of coalescent-based population size history inference beyond two million years ago. Specifically, we discuss an ancient inferred peak in effective population size around 5-7Mya seen in PSMC analysis of human and chimpanzee genomes, but not in gorilla or orangutan. While this peak has been partially observed in several previous studies in humans and chimpanzees [2, 8, 9, 16, 26, 27], it has received little attention in the literature. We present a revised analysis of this peak using modern data and discuss its potential implications for understanding the evolutionary history of humans and other great apes. We take care to address potential model violations and other factors that may affect the reliability of these inferences. Overall, our study suggests that we may be able to significantly extend the applicability of coalescent-based inference much further into the past, generating new insights into the complex history of hominin evolution.

sec.title: An ancient peak in human and chimpanzee population size history
sec.p: We separately inferred an effective population size (N(t)) curve over time for 26 single diploid genome sequences, each from a distinct population in the 1000 Genomes Project [28, 29, 27, 30] (1000GP) using PSMC (Figure 1a). Importantly, we extended previous similar analyses by fitting the model with fewer parameter constraints [31] and using the high coverage (30x) whole-genome sequencing data resource [30], allowing greater resolution at time scales >2Mya (see Methods). The resulting N(t) estimates start between 5 kya and end around 10Mya, which is deeper in the past than in previous studies [2, 8, 9, 26]. In all human samples two peaks can be seen, one around the time of appearance of modern humans approximately 200kya and a second older one, starting around 2Mya going backwards in time, reaching a maximum around 5.5Mya with a population size of ~37,500, then decreasing until around 10Ma. While the ancient peak is partially visible in previous whole-genome analyses [2, 9, 26], it is frequently truncated or represented with poor resolution because of the way time intervals were specified. 30 iterations of block bootstrapping reveals there is less variance in N(t) in ancient time than there is recent time (Figure A1).

As the ancient peak occurs around the estimated period of human and chimpanzee species separation, it is natural to ask if a similar signal exists in chimpanzee population size history, or in other great apes in general. We therefore used PSMC to infer the population size history from 79 great ape genomes, as in [16] (see Methods). First, we recovered an ancient peak in chimpanzees and bonobos, overlapping the peak seen in the human analysis, though perhaps with its maximum slightly older (Figure 1b). This extends a similar signal further back in time, present in previous analyses but not discussed [16]. As with humans, our re-analysis produces the ancient peak more clearly because we avoid grouping old time intervals. We note that the effective population size of the chimpanzee ancient peak is significantly higher than that of humans. The fact that the peaks observed in humans and chimpanzees align with the time frame of their estimated divergence prompts the question of whether these peaks signify a shared history between the two species. Indeed, as we discuss in the Appendix, correcting for mutation rate variations in time, as well as for variable generation times, in principle could align the two population size curves, both in their time period and their scale. However, uncertainty in these parameters, as well as in curve estimation, precludes a confident conclusion.

For gorillas (Figure 1c) and orangutans (Figure 1d), we do not detect a discernible peak in the region between 5-10Mya. This is consistent with the fact that gorillas and orangutans genetically separated from humans and chimpanzees prior to the 5-7Mya time period, and so would not be expected to share their history at that time. Moreover, it supports the claim that the ancient peak is not an artefact of the method or of the data processing, as that would result in a peak with gorillas and orangutans as well.

sec.title: The fraction of uncoalesced genome as a function of time
sec.p: The power of PSMC to infer N(t) at 5.5Mya relies on there being sufficiently many places in the genome where the two input lineages coalesce more anciently than this time. To assess whether this is reasonable to expect, we note that under a simple panmictic model the observed range of heterozygosity in humans (e.g., ∼0.00069 for PEL to ∼0.001 for MSL in 1000GP) would correspond to a constant effective diploid population size of 13,800-20,000, using a mutation rate of 1.25e-8 per base pair per generation. Given an exponential distribution of coalescence times, and a generation time of 30 years, we expect a mean coalescence time of 828,000-1,200,000 years, and that the coalescence time will be older than 5.5Mya in 0.12%-1.01% of the genome, which would be sufficient to provide plenty of information for this period, in particular taking note that older regions of coalescence are correspondingly shorter than younger ones.

As more direct confirmation from the data, we inferred the fraction of the genome that has not yet coalesced as a function of time for the 1000GP samples, using PSMC decoding (see Methods). At least 1% of the genome is estimated not to have coalesced by 5Mya, and approximately 0.1% by 10Mya (Figure 2a). Ancient regions tend to be shared among individuals (Figure 2b); e.g. positions with an inferred posterior mean TMRCA of over 3Mya show an average correlation of r2=0.21 across individuals (Figure A2). We note that further back in time, segments of shared ancestry become increasingly shorter because of longer exposure to recombination, and that these are scattered across the genome. For example we estimate that African individuals harbor roughly 4,000 non-contiguous segments whose coalescence time is older than 4Mya (Table 1; see Methods). We note that previous simulation studies [32, 33] and theoretical analysis [34] have shown that posterior mean estimates of true ancient coalescent times substantially older than the mean tend to be significantly downward biased, which may indicate an even older age for detected ancient regions. We repeated the analysis using an independent method, Relate [35], which does not rely on the PSMC assumptions and uses multiple sequences jointly; this also identifies sufficient coalescence material exists in this time period (see Methods and Figure A3). We further note that if we alter the time discretisation parameters in PSMC, then the inference of human N(t) is almost consistent in each population until ∼20Mya (Figure A4), at which point it begins to fray as likely the genome is fully coalesced.

sec.title: Model violations and their effects
sec.p: As with all statistical frameworks, the PSMC method relies on specific modelling assumptions that may not hold true in reality. Deviations from these assumptions could have varying impacts on inference across different temporal scales, and could potentially account for some or all of the observed ancient peak. We therefore considered how departures from the modelling assumptions could plausibly affect inference of population size history in the deep past.

To this end, we considered the following possible issues. First, repeats may manifest as an artifactual heterozygous signal, leading to long segments with high heterozygosity, which then leads to an apparent excess of ancient coalescence events. Second, variation in mutation rates across different genomic regions could cause some regions to have a higher density of mutations leading to an interpretation as having a more ancient TMRCA, and hence systematic biases in the inference of accurate evolutionary histories. Third, the human mutation rate is estimated to have slowed down over time [36, 37, 38, 39], while in PSMC it is assumed constant. Fourth, variability in recombination rates across the genome (in particular at recombination hotspots) is also a departure from model assumptions [40, 41, 42, 43, 44]. Fifth, at longer timescales there may become a significant probability of recurrent mutations at the same site, which are not modelled in PSMC. Sixth, background selection, which has been estimated to be pervasive in humans [45, 46], has been shown to distort the inference of the coalescence rate [47, 48, 49]. Finally, balancing selection can also manifest as an excess in ancient coalescence events.

We conducted an extensive set of simulation studies to analyse how these violations may affect inference, which we describe fully in the Appendix). We concluded that it is unlikely any of these issues or violations could cause a false ancient peak of the type we see in real data. Notably, we observed that if there are large variations in the mutation rate across the genome, then false inflations of inferred N(t) are observed. However, the degree of rate variation required to generate this is larger than the degree of this inferred in humans, and moreover their ancient inferred N(t) has high variance, contrasting the low variance we have shown in humans in the ∼5Mya peak.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have demonstrated the applicability of coalescent-based inference to examine deep evolutionary history (five million years ago and beyond) in the hominin lineage. Specifically, we highlighted and extended the analysis of a peak in ancient population size history inferred by PSMC, which is reliably estimated from human, chimpanzee and bonobo data, though not found in gorillas or orangutans. The human, chimpanzee and bonobo peaks span approximately the same time period, suggesting that they may reflect the same event prior to, or during, human-chimpanzee speciation. We discussed several ways in which the data may violate the model underlying our analysis, and concluded that none are likely to generate a false ancient peak.

A straightforward interpretation of an ancient peak is that it reflects true changes in population size. Indeed, for humans, changes in inferred N(t) since ∼80kya have been associated with the out-of-Africa event followed by more recent recent population size increases [3, 6]. The ancient peak may similarly reflect ancient hominin population expansion and decline in the late miocene and the pliocene. To the extent the same ancient peak exists in chimpanzees and bonobos, it may reflect common environmental conditions affecting similar evolutionary processes in the different species.

However, there are other possible explanations. The separation and reconnection of local populations alters the amount of possible gene flow between them, which affects the inferred N(t) [2, 50, 24, 51]. In a structured population, the coalescence rate decreases relative to a panmictic population of the same size, thus the effective population size (taken here as the inverse of the coalescence rate) increases. Indeed, in [24] the authors show that the inferred human effective population size as inferred by PSMC, including the ancient peak, can be equally well obtained by a set of populations with varying migration rates between them without any changes in size. Therefore, it is possible that the ancient peak is a signature of ancient population structure or other departures from panmixia.

One such possible structured event may be complex speciation between humans and chimpanzees, in which after an initial split the two populations rejoined or exchanged genes for a period of time. Previous publications have put forward evidence for this type of model [18, 19, 13, 20], although other analysis has favoured a model with a clean split [21, 22]. Innan and Watanabe proposed there was no strong support for gene flow after divergence, and that a clean split best fit the data [21]. This result was reinforced by Yamamichi, whose maximum likelihood model also favoured a clean split [22]. Patterson et al. proposed that gene flow did occur, because of differences in the estimated divergence time between the autosomes and X chromosome [18], although this approach has been criticised [52, 53, 22]. Using a likelihood ratio test considering divergence times across the genome, Yang rejected the null hypothesis of an absence of gene flow [19]. With an HMM that explicitly tests for immediate or prolonged separation, Mailund et al. proposed that a model with an extended period of gene flow better fits the data [13]. Galtier introduced Aphid, which distinguishes between discordant coalescent trees (ones that do not match the species trees) generated by ILS or gene flow [20]. It leverages the fact that multispecies coalescent trees affected by gene flow tend to have shorter branches, and coalescent trees affected by incomplete lineage sorting longer branches, than the average coalescent tree. This information provided strong support for a model in which there was ancient gene flow between human, chimpanzee, and even gorilla, after the initial human-chimpanzee split.

If the peak we observed in chimpanzees and bonobos is indeed reliable and aligned with the ancient peak observed in humans, this may be consistent with a period of ongoing gene flow after initial human and chimpanzee separation. Qualitatively, there are other observations which make this type of model attractive. Notably, CoalHMM [23] and TRAILS [17] assume a panmictic ancestral human-chimpanzee population and estimate its size as 177,368 and 167,400, respectively. Both of these estimates are more than 8 times the long-term effective population size of humans and chimpanzees (in both species, θ = 4Nμ is roughly 0.001, which assuming μ=1.25e-8 gives N=20,000), and are not well aligned with the PSMC inference in this period (Figure 1). A structured ancestral population could explain the large CoalHMM and TRAILS estimates, as falsely assuming panmixia can inflate estimates of population size [24]. Moreover, Aphid [20], which provides strong support for human-chimp-gorilla gene flow, estimates the size of the ancestral human-chimpanzee population to be of similar size to present day human, chimpanzee and bonobo populations. Additionally, chimpanzees and bonobos have been estimated to split cleanly around 2Mya [13], and PSMC does not infer a unique peak around this period. Finally, widespread structure in the ancestral populations of humans, chimpanzees/bonobos, and gorillas, may plausibly explain why fossils such as Sahelanthropus from this period are hard to assign [54, 55, 56], and as a consequence morphological analyses can not confidently determine separation times [57].

We examined the sensitivity of PSMC to various modelling violations such as variation in mutation and recombination rates, and selection. It will be useful to incorporate these as extensions to the PSMC model, modifying the transition and emission probabilities within the underlying HMM accordingly. Indeed, some work has already been done towards this goal [58, 59], and future modification could further address slowdown or genomic variability in mutation rate, recombination hotspots, and/or selection, so as to better understand the ancient speciation process in primates [17] and indeed other species.

sec.title: Processing data
sec.p: We took high-coverage whole-genome-sequence cram files for one individual in each of the 26 populations from the 1000 Genomes project. These are aligned to GRCh38. The cram files were converted to bam and indexed with samtools [60, 61]. The genotype likelihoods were calculated with bcftools mpileup [62] by skipping alignments with mapping quality less than 20, skipping bases with base alignment quality less than 20, and setting the coefficient for downgrading mapping quality to 50. SNPs were called using bcftools and all indels were excluded. Variants were then designated as uncallable if the minimum mapping quality was less than 20, the minimum consensus quality was less than 20, or the coverage was less than half or more than double the mean coverage. Finally, we designated all regions in the strict mappability mask for GRCh38 (ftp.1000genomes.ebi.ac.uk/vol1/ftp/data_collections/1000_genomes_project/working/20160622_genome_mask_GRCh38) as uncallable. Uncallable positions are labelled as missing data in the HMM.

We downloaded processed primate data from eichlerlab.gs.washington.edu/greatape/data/ [16]. We took the VCF files and masked positions according to the given bed files, which described sites where coverage was less than 5 and regions that did not pass the quality filters as discussed in their paper. After filtering, only 49% of the genome was designated as callable. For the eastern lowland gorilla, we arbitrarily chose the individual labelled “Mkubwa”, and for the Nigeria-Cameroon chimpanzee we chose the individual labelled “Akwaya Jean”. We note that analysis on other individuals looked similar. For the gorilla we used a mutation rate per base pair per generation of 1.43e-08, and a generation time of 19 years; for the chimpanzee, a mutation rate per base pair per generation of 1.78e-08 and a generation time of 24 years were used [36].

sec.title: Mutation rates and generation times for humans and primates
sec.p: In humans we set the generation time as 29 [63] and the mutation rate per generation per base pair as μ=1.25e-08 [64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69, 70]. The rates we set for the other great apes are taken from [39]. In chimpanzees and bonobos we set μ=1.78e-08 and generation time equal to 24 years. For Gorillas we set μ=1.42e-08 and generation time equal to 19 years. For Orangutans we set μ=2.03e-08 and generation time equal to 27.

sec.title: PSMC analysis
sec.p: We ran PSMC as embedded in cobraa, www.github.com/trevorcousins/cobraa. We used 64 time intervals and enabled the parameters for the effective population size in each to be inferred freely. This contrasts the default settings of previous implementations of the algorithm that force adjacent intervals to be the same, which has been shown to lead to fitting problems [31]. In the 1000GP data, we fixed the scaled mutation rate θ as 0.0008 which is roughly the mean across populations. For the great apes, we fixed the θ for gorilas as 0.0014, chimpanzees and bonobos as 0.001, and orangutans as 0.0014. We found that fixing this parameter reduces noise in the estimation of ancient N(t), and also forces time interval boundaries across individuals to align. The initial value for the ratio of mutation rate to recombination rate was set as 1.5, and the recombination rate was set to be inferred as part of the EM algorithm, which was iterated for 30 iterations. The time interval boundaries are controlled by equation (1) where D is the number of discrete time boundaries (we used 64 throughout), and ω and Tmax control the spread of time interval boundaries. In Figure 1 we used ω=0.01 and Tmax=50; in Figure A4 we used ω=0.01 and Tmax=150.

sec.title: PSMC decoding
sec.p: Using the inferred effective population size parameters, scaled recombination rate, and scaled mutation rate (θ=0.0008), we used the PSMC decoding to get a posterior probability of coalescence at every position. To calculate the amount of uncoalesced genome over time, we integrated over the full posterior probability (Figure 2). To scale from time in coalescent units (equation (1)) to time in years, we used N=16,000 (θ = 4Nμ= 0.0008 with μ=1.25e-08) then multiplied coalescent time by 2Nμg, where g is the number of years per generations. To get a point estimate from PSMC (Figure 2b), we take the posterior mean at each position using the midpoint of the time interval boundaries.

To calculate the number of ancient non-contiguous segments inferred in different African populations (Table 1), we looked for regions where the posterior probability of coalescence as old or older than 2Mya, 3Mya, or 4Mya, respectively, is greater than 0.9. We then only counted non-contiguous segments, which are all segments that are not adjacent.

sec.title: Nonparametric bootstrapping
sec.p: For a given individual, for each chromosome, we break the sequence up into segments of 5Mb, then reconstruct a new sequence by sampling with replacement from all 5Mb segments. These are then concatenated together to form a contiguous sequence, on which PSMC inference is performed using 30 iterations. This procedure is repeated 30 times for humans and 30 times for chimps.

sec.title: Relate
sec.p: We ran Relate [35] on all samples on the 1000GP for GBP, CHB, and YRI. We randomly selected 10 diploid sequences from each population. To calculate the fraction of uncoalesced genome we discretised time into intervals of 500 generations and computed a histogram based on Relate’s ARG. The inferred fraction of uncoalesced genome at 5Mya was roughly 0.3%, for each sample in each population.

sec.title: Reproducibility
sec.p: Key scripts that were used for analysis have been uploaded to https://github.com/trevorcousins/twin_peaks.
